message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition where the normal cells lining the esophagus are replaced by cells that resemble those that line the intestine, including goblet cells which secrete mucus. The other options are not typically found in the normal esophageal lining.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition where the non-specialized columnar epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by specialized columnar epithelium, complete with goblet cells that secrete mucus. Therefore, the abnormal cell type present in this patient’s esophagus is goblet cells. Option (A) describes the normal cell type of the esophagus, option (B) is not found in the esophagus, and option (D) is not related to the condition described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition where the normal squamous cells of the esophagus are replaced by columnar cells that produce mucus, similar to those seen in the intestine. These cells are known as goblet cells. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) goblet cells. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is the normal tissue type found in the esophagus. Simple cuboidal epithelium is more commonly found in glandular tissue. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes are white blood cells that are involved in inflammation and fighting off infection, but they are not typically found in the esophagus in this context.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia means that the normal squamous cells in the esophagus have transformed into columnar cells with goblet cells like those that line the intestine. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Goblet cells. All other options are not consistent with intestinal metaplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by intestinal-type epithelium. This type of epithelium is characterized by the presence of goblet cells, which secrete mucus to protect against acid reflux. Therefore, (C) is the correct answer. The other options are normal cells found in other parts of the body or in healthy esophageal tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition in which there is a change in the cell type lining the esophagus, whereby glandular cells similar to those in the intestine replace squamous cells. Goblet cells are commonly seen in intestinal metaplasia, so (C) is the correct answer. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and simple cuboidal epithelium are not types of cells found in the esophagus, and polymorphonuclear leukocytes are associated with inflammation and infection, not metaplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia in the esophagus is a precursor for esophageal adenocarcinoma and is characterized by the growth of intestinal-like epithelium with goblet cells. Among the options, only goblet cells are present in intestinal metaplasia. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is the normal type of tissue in the esophagus, while simple cuboidal epithelium and polymorphonuclear leukocytes are not typically found in the esophagus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is characterized by the abnormal presence of goblet cells, which are typically not found in the esophagus. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is the normal cell type found in the esophagus. Simple cuboidal epithelium and polymorphonuclear leukocytes are not typically found in the esophagus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition in which the cells in the esophagus change to resemble cells in the intestines. Goblet cells are present in the intestine, and their presence in the esophagus suggests intestinal metaplasia. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is the normal cell type in the esophagus, and simple cuboidal epithelium is not found in the esophagus. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes are not related to intestinal metaplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intestinal metaplasia is a condition where the normal cells lining the esophagus are replaced by cells that are normally found in the intestines. One of these cells is goblet cells, which secrete mucus to protect the intestinal lining. The other options are not associated with intestinal metaplasia.
